loans.name: Liezl

texts.en:
Liezl is 22 years old, and single. She requested a loan in order to purchase boxes of milk, snack foods, drinks, canned goods and different products for daily needs. She started her business a year ago. It was her mother’s business, but she inherited it. She used to help her mother prepare and serve customers. 

She is happy with the loan she received, because she will buy supplies needed to keep her customers happy. Her business matters, because it helps her financially. She is happy when people are satisfied with the service provided. She feels proud when they tell her that her store has complete products so that they don't need to go to the town just to buy. She uses the earnings to invest for the future when she will build her own family. 

She hopes to build a house on a piece of land when she has her own family. She also hopes for her business to continue to grow, in order to provide a better life for her parents, and for them to have what they need.

loans.use: to purchase snack foods, drinks and canned goods for her store.

loans.name: Socorro

texts.en:
Socorro is 48 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married. 

Socorro has a food shop that sells pork & chicken barbecue, caldereta & afritada. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy raw ingredients needed for making viands.

Socorro is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Socorro hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed for making prepared foods.

loans.name: Nicholson

texts.en:
Nicholson is 32 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married and has 7 children. 

Nicholson has a shop in which he sells sunglasses, hair accessories, nail cutters & combs. He has had this business for a few years. He has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy inventory of sunglasses & accessories to sell.

Nicholson  is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Nicholson hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy stocks like shades & accessories to sell.

loans.name: Elvis

texts.en:
This is Elvis, 36, a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. He is married to Irene, his business partner and mother to his three children. Elvis, together with his wife, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, he is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Elvis operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails in groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Elvis earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Aside from the store, he is also involved in direct selling. He sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands. A customer’s order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. His store is located adjacent to his house. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community. He earns a minimum of PHP1400 in sales every day.

To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a PHP50,000 loan. He will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand his product inventory. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. 

Elvis dreams to be able to give his children a good and high quality education through all his hard work on his business. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship* members to share stories of his work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in his business.

loans.name: Camila

texts.en:
Camila is 45 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed. 

Camila has a food shop that sells viands like caldereta, pancit bihon & afritada. She has had this business for a few years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy raw ingredients for making viands.

Camila is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Camila hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making viands.

loans.name: Luzviminda

texts.en:
Luzviminda is 48 years old and has been operating a sari-sari store for ten years. A sari-sari means variety wherein it has the concept of tingi; a customer can buy 'units' of the product rather than the whole package. For example, one can buy one pc. of candy for a peso rather than a whole pack. She sells biscuits, vinegar and cooking oil in her store that one can buy as tingi.

She was blessed with seven children, all of whom are studying. It is hard to send them all at the same time, but she never feels it is hardship, but instead, she is very inspired to work as she repeatedly states they are her blessings from God to give their needs.

She is requesting a loan amount PHP7, 000 to buy soft drinks, salt, and sugar as additional commodity to her store. She hopes that she will generate more income through these goods to have savings for the education of her children.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, salt, and sugar as additional commodities for her store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase high grade manure for his farm.

loans.name: Angeline

texts.en:
Angeline is 27 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is single and has 2 children. 

Angeline makes and sells snacks like rice & pancakes. She has had this business for 5 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy raw ingredients for making snacks.

Angeline is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Angeline hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for making snacks.

loans.name: Phuc

texts.en:
Phuc is a 29 year old singL. woman living in Ho Chi Minh City. Phuc earns a living by running a general store, which she has done for the past 5 years. She intends to use her loan to buy a greater variety and quantity of basic goods such as snack foods and confectionery items to sell in her store. She hopes this will enabL. her to better meet the needs of her customers and to attract additional customers.

Phuc hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to generate additional income to reinvest in her business and improve her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy a greater range and quantity of goods to stock her general store.

loans.name: Nhan

texts.en: Nhan is a housewife. Her husband is a construction worker earning $2 per day for his income. She has two children, 5 years old and 2 months old. The older one is studying. Every month, she spends $80 on food, $10 on school fees, and $5 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $600 to buy a motorbike for her husband to travel to work and also to provide motor taxi service when he is off work. She wants to help her husband to earn money to support the family so she has a plan to buy grocery goods to sell at home when she can save enough money.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her husband's travel to work.

loans.name: Cares

texts.en:
Cares is 31 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married and has 3 children. 

Cares has a retail shop from which she sells clothing like t-shirts, blouses & underwear. She has had this business for 5 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy clothing, like t-shirts & blouses.

Cares is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Cares hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy clothing like t-shirts & blouses.

loans.name: Masimba Group

texts.en: This is 44-year-old Ruth (in purple) from Masvingo, a town in south-eastern Zimbabwe. She is married with three children, all attending school. She also cares for three dependents. Ruth runs a retail cross-border business selling stoves, fridges, and clothing. The business has been in operation for 17 years. She says the main challenge faced is meeting market demand due to capital constraints. Ruth has requested a loan of $400 to buy fridges for resale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to take better care of her dependents and family members. In the future, Ruth plans to own a shop where she can sell her goods.

loans.use: to buy fridges for resale

loans.name: Darin

texts.en: Darin, 62 years old, is a cake seller earning $4 per day for her income. She has three children, one is studying and the other two are working, earning $2.5 per day. Every month, she spends $50 on food, $27 on school fees, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $600 to buy a motorbike for her children's travel to studying. She never wants to change her career because she is an expert in making cakes to sell and she can make a good income for her family. She hopes to send her children to study at the university when they finish high school.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her children traveling to studying.

loans.name: Chanoun

texts.en:
Chanoun, 46 years old, is a grocery seller. Her husband is a motor taxi driver, their income is $8 per day. She has three children, all of them are studying. 

Every month, she spends $70 on food, $5 on electricity, $40 on school fee, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $700 to buy a Tok Tok for her husband to do a Tok Tok (motorized three-wheel rickshaw) service. 

She hopes her husband's new career can earn a better income than the previous career so that she is able to send her children to study in the university when they finish high school.

loans.use: to buy a Tok Tok for her husband's career.

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson is 38 years old and lives in the Philippines. He is married and has 6 children. 

Nelson has a shop where he sells canned goods, beverages & snacks. He has had this business for 12 years. He has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

Nelson is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Nelson hopes to improve his business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages.

loans.name: Nem

texts.en:
Nem, 63 years old, is selling food and sweets. Her husband is a motorbike repairer, their income is $6 per day. She has three children, all of them are working earning a combined $10 per day for all. 

Every month, Nem spends $80 on food, $10 on electricity, and $20 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $500 to buy material for repairing her house because it is now not in good condition to live. In the future, she hopes to run her current career well and be better than before. She hopes that she can make a better income to repair her house again to live in good standard.

loans.use: to buy material for repairing her house.

loans.name: Pantaleona

texts.en:
Pantaleona is 62 years old, and lives in the Philippines. She is married with seven children. 
Pantaleona has a retail shop that sells fish like sardines and mackerels. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy fish to sell.
Pantaleona is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Pantaleona hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa is 44 years old, and lives in the Philippines. She is married, and has five children. 
Teresa has a retail shop that sells firewood. She has had this business for three years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy firewood to sell.
Teresa is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Teresa hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy firewood to sell.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is 47 years old and married to a farmer. She is engaged in the buying and selling of fruits and vegetables. She sells bananas and string beans. They have a little plantation where her husband plants bananas and vegetables, while she is responsible for selling in the market and house-to-house in the harvesting season.
     
She is requesting a loan of 15,000 Philippines pesos (P) to buy string beans, eggplants and onions as additional vegetables to plant in their land. She has five children, and three of them are studying. Two of the children are helping financially through planting vegetables in their land. 

She is earning P5,000 each month, but it's not enough for them, so she budgets wisely to avoid lack of allowances and expenses of her school-aged children.

loans.use: to buy string beans, eggplants and onions as additional vegetables to plant.

loans.name: Rutchie

texts.en:
Rutchie is 44 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married. 

Rutchie has a retail shop that sells canned goods, beverages and snacks. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan of 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Rutchie is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, Rutchie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Rosemarie

texts.en:
Rosemarie is 44 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with five children. 

Rosemarie has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for five years. She requested a loan of 5,000 Philippines pesos (PHP) to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Rosemarie is a new member of HSPFI. In the future,Rosemarie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Saodat

texts.ru: Саодат проживает в районе Яван. Ей 45 лет. Она замужем. У нее четверо детей. Ее муж находится на заработках заграницей. Сама Саодат зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. Этим видом деятельности она занимается 10 лет. Кредит берет для закупа мелко - рогатого скота. Она хочет купить несколько козлят в дальнейшем для продажи.
texts.en: Saodat lives in the Yavan region. She is 45 years old, married and has four children. Her husband is now working abroad. Saodat makes a living herself by breeding large horned cattle. She has been in this business for ten years. She is taking out the loan to buy small horned cattle. She wants to buy a few goat kids for future resale.

loans.use: to buy small horned cattle

loans.name: Roberta

texts.en:
Roberta, 48, lives in the Philippines and is married with two children.

She has a retail shop that sells canned goods, beverages and snacks, a business she has had for six years. She has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages .

Roberta is a new member of HSPFI. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Bayarsaihan

texts.en:
Bayarsaihan, 26, lives with his family in a ger, a Mongolian yurt, in the Huvsgul province of Mongolia. His wife works as a hairdresser at a beauty salon and his daugther attends local high school. Bayarsaihan started to sell clothes with his sister in 2009. Aside from this business, he runs a block manufacturing factory at his home. So far, his businesses are running successfully. He plans to purchase many clothes and goods before the new school year starts.

He is a hardworking and diligent man who says "I want to buy many clothes and goods before September when the sales will go up dramatically." He is requesting 1,500,000 MNT to purchase clothes and increase his sales turnover.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: Paz

texts.en:
Paz, 52, is married and lives in the Philippines. She has a retail shop that sells a variety of dried fish and has had this business for 15 years. She has requested a loan of 7,000 PHP to buy dried fish to sell.

Paz has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, she hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy dried fish to sell.

loans.name: Khanh

texts.en:
Khanh, 53, is a married man with two children living in Ho Chi Minh city. His wife works as a small trader.

Khanh earns an income to support his family by running a general store, which he has run for the past seven years. He intends to use his loan to buy a greater variety and quantity of basic good such as packaged foods, snacks and beverages to stock his store and better serve his customers.

He hopes his business runs smoothly and will help him to earn a higher income to reinvest in his business and save money for his children's education.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety and quantity of basic goods to stock his general store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda is a farmer’s wife, living in a barrio with their six children. A barrio is a traditional division of a municipality officially delineated by the local authority. She is 56 but, because of extreme poverty, she continues to look for an income just to send her children to school to finish their education so that they may avoid the hardships of life which they are experiencing right now.

Rosalinda operates a store, selling candies, vinegar and cooking oil. She earns a net income of 2,000 PHP a month but this is not enough to cover their basic needs. Rosalinda stated that they are used to eating salt for breakfast. So, when she heard about Alalay Sa Kaunlaran Inc. and their program to help the needy, she requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to buy soft drinks and bread as additional goods to sell in her store. She hopes that it will allow her to meet the demands of her customers in order to generate more income to provide for her family's basic needs, such as food.

She is thankful that God gave her ASKI and extends her thanks to ASKI for the great service and companionship to needy people such as her.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks and bread for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, sugar and cooking oil.

loans.name: Muzaffar

texts.ru: Музаффар житель Яванского района. Ему 35 лет. Женат. Имеет 4 детей. Его жена домохозяйка. Сам он занимается животноводством. Он в основном откармливает и продает скот. Этим видом деятельности занимается восемь лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Muzaffar lives in the Yavan region.  He's thirty-five, married, and has four children.  His wife is a homemaker.  He makes a living raising livestock, mainly cattle, for sale.  He's been in the field for eight years.  He plans to use his loan to buy long-horned cattle.

loans.use: to buy long-horned cattle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a hand cart for water distribution and food stock for his restaurant.

loans.name: Baltazar

texts.en:
Baltazar lives with his five children. He manages a farming business in which he plants and harvests corn. Aside from farming, he is also engaged in a hog raising business. He’s been doing it for almost one year.

Baltazar has two children he is sending to school, and both are in the high school level. His elder child did not enter college because of lack of finances, and goes to Manila to work as a household helper. Baltazar's big wish is that he could be able to send his children to school until college and finish their studies.

At the moment, Baltazar is requesting a loan to buy additional piglets to raise. He hopes that through the loan he will develop his hog raising business and increase his profits.

loans.use: to buy additional piglets to raise.

loans.name: Eliza

texts.en:
Eliza is 26 years old and married with three children. One of her children is in school. She has a business selling bread in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been running this business for two years. 

Eliza requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bread and cake to sell

loans.name: Paz

texts.en:
This is Paz, 41, resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Joey, a driver, and is the mother to their three children. Two are in high school while the youngest is still staying at home. She, together with her husband and children, manages their household while operating a business. 

Paz operates a junk shop. Trash is not actively separated in the Philippines, and while waiting for their local dump trucks, people scavenge garbage dumps and trash bags for recyclable materials like metal, copper, plastic, paper and other materials. They sell these to junk shops like Paz's for a little profit. Junk shops then stack, clean, and gather huge quantities of these materials and sell them back to foundries like factories and others of the like. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 1,000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 20,000 loan. She will be incorporating the loan into her current revolving fund used to buy trash from collectors. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Paz hopes to buy a van to transport the scrap materials she collects. She also hopes to have her house renovated by the end of the year. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members* to share stories of her work every week, and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for materials and items she buys in her junk shop business.

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en:
Thuy is 48 years old and married. She has two children and lives with them and her husband in Ho Chi Minh City. Thuy’s husband works as a laborer and porter.

Thuy earns an income to support her family by selling clothing, which she has done for the past six years. She plans to use this loan to buy a greater variety and quantity of clothes to sell. She hopes this will enable her to better meet the needs of her current customers and attract additional customers.  

She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her family's living conditions and to save money for her children's education.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety and quantity of clothes to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more crates of both hard and soft beverages to resell at his pub.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase chairs and tables for his restaurant, and to purchase four hand carts for water distribution.

loans.name: Dep

texts.en:
Dep is a 56-year-old married woman living in Ho Chi Minh city. Dep has 4 children. Dep’s husband works as a driver.

Dep earns an income to support her family by operating a beauty salon together with a general store in the front of her house. She has done this for 4 years. She plans to use this loan to buy a greater variety of basic goods to stock her store.
  
She hopes that this will enable her to increase the turnover of her business, earn a higher income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy a greater variety and quantity of basic goods to stock her general store.

loans.name: Mtoni Group

texts.en:
Zainabu, who is in her mid 40s, is married with five children who go to school. She has been operating a fruits and vegetables business for six years now.  She works from 6 am to 8 pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be her 1st loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She wants a loan to buy more fruits and vegetables to sell. Her dream is to one day be able to open a food shop.

She will share this loan with her loan group, "Mtoni", which has a total of 23 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetables to sell.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 38 years old, married and blessed with three children. She is an elementary school graduate who is hopeful of lifting her family from poverty. She has a sari-sari (variety) store where she sells toothpaste, shampoo, conditioner, vinegar, sugar, and salt. She engaged in this business to earn and save for the education of her two school-aged children.

As a store owner, having a creditor is not avoidable, so Maria sees to it that her business will not suffer from the credit of her neighborhood. She is asking a loan amount of Php 8,000 to buy soft drinks, breads and eggs as additional goods to sell in her store. She is thankful that Alalay Sa Kaunlaran Inc. approved her loan.

She hopes that her store will grow and earn a higher income so that they will never experience eating without meat.  Maria wants to continue her dreams through her children. She wants her children to finish school, a vital thing that she never did because of the hardships of life.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks, breads and eggs as additional goods to sell.

loans.name: Thanh

texts.en:
Thanh is a 48-year-old married woman living in Ho Chi Minh city. She has 2 children. Her husband works as a mechanic.

To support her family, Thanh runs a business producing machinery parts and casings. She has run this business for 5 years. She plans to use this loan to buy more metal and materials to make more machinery parts and casings to sell, which will enable her to better meet the needs of her customers.

She hopes her business runs smoothly and will help her to improve her family's living conditions and to save money to reinvest in her business.

loans.use: to buy more metal and materials for making machinery parts and casings.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes and shoes for resale

loans.name: Catherin

texts.en: Catherin is 43 years old. She is a widow with five children, all of whom are in school. She has a business selling clothes in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years. Catherin requested this loan from BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes to sell

loans.name: Ernalyn

texts.en:
Ernalyn is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children.

Ernalyn has a fruit shop that sells lanzones (a fruit) by the kilogram. She has had this business for 4 years. She requested a loan of 17,000 PHP to buy a box or bunch of lanzones to sell.

Ernalyn has been a member of HSPFI since 2009. In the future, Ernalyn hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy a box or bunch of lanzones to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a handcart for water distribution business

loans.name: Salamata

texts.fr:
Mme Salamata est mariée et mère de 02 enfants. Le plus âgé a 12ans et le moins âgé a 09ans. Tous les 02 vont à l’école. Elle a 02 personnes en charge.

Elle vend du d’aigue et du yaourt depuis 14ans. Mme s’approvisionne au carrefour de la patte d’oie en ville à Ouagadougou. Ses clients sont ses amis, ses voisins et alentour.

Elle veut s’acheter 02 sacs de lait et 04 sacs de petit mil.

Mme économise pour renforcer son activité. Elle ambitionne ouvrir un grand daiguedrom et aider son mari à s’occuper de sa famille et de la scolarisation de ses enfants.
texts.en: Ms. Salamata is a married mother of two children. The elder is 12 years old, and the younger is 9. Both of them go to school. She has two persons to support. She has been selling milk and yoghurt for fourteen years. She gets her supplies at the Patte d'Oie crossroad in the town of Ouagadougou. Her customers are her friends, neighbors, and those nearby. Ms. Salamata wants to buy 2 bags of milk and 4 bags of pearl millet. She is saving money to bolster her business. Her ambition is to open a large daiguedrom and to help out her husband to take care of her family and the children's education.

loans.use: to buy milk and pearl millet

loans.name: Serigne Bara Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Serigne Bara a été créé le 22/07/2011.IL est composé de 16 femmes issues du même village. Elles ont pour activité le petit commerce et l'agriculture.

Madame Dié en position assise sur la photo et à l’extrême droite, est responsable du groupement,elle est âgée de 64 ans et a 04 enfants.

Son activité est l'agriculture,elle cultive le mil et l'arachide.Elle dispose d'une bonne expérience de ce type d'activité pour l'avoir pratiqué depuis sa jeunesse.

Son prêt lui permettra de s'approvisionner en semences et intrants.

Son objectif est de faire de l'élevage,le commerce de légumes et la réfection de sa maison.
texts.en:
The Serigne Bara solidarity group was created on July 22, 2011. It consists of 16 women from the same village who conduct small trade and farming.

Mrs Dié, sitting on the far right-hand side of the photo, chairs the group. She is 64 years old and the mother of four children. She is a farmer and grows millet and groundnuts. She has a lot of experience in this activity after having worked in farming since her youth. She will use her loan to buy seeds and agricultural supplies. Her goal is to rear cattle, sell vegetables and repair her house.

loans.use: to buy seeds of millet and groundnuts.

loans.name: Ma. Jean

texts.en:
This is Maria Jean, 42, a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Joselito, a driver, and is the mother of three children, two of whom are already in college, while the youngest is in high school. By the grace of God, Maria Jean has managed to support her older children's schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to send her youngest to high school. Like most Filipino parents, Maria Jean believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Maria Jean maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fullerlife, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue and these are the profits that dealers are investing as their income. She also earns by selling Tupperware and through tutorial services. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 1,800 Philippine pesos (PHP) in sales every week.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a 17,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy merchandise items and Tupperware products for her customers. A portion of the loan will be used to purchase materials for her tutorial service. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Maria Jean fervently hopes that she’ll have a store for the products she’s selling. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for merchandise items and products needed in her business

loans.name: Alimaa

texts.en:
Alimaa is 44 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in a house in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her eldest daughter attends high school and her youngest daughter goes to the kindergarden. Her husband is a taxi driver.

She used to sell blankets and sheets at Narantuul market between 2004 and 2008. Since 2008, she has been selling the same products at Han Talst market. Her total turnover capital is 2.5 million MNT and her daily income is between 50,000 MNT and 100,000 MNT. Her revenue is about 40% of her income. She has collected much business experience in past years.

She is a hardworking and diligent woman who says, "I want to expand my business activity." She is requesting a 2,500,000 MNT loan to buy more products to increase her sales turnover.

loans.use: to buy more products

loans.name: Dioubo Group

texts.fr:
le groupe de solidarité Dioubo a été créé le 09/05/2010.IL est composé de 21 femmes issues du même village.
Elles ont comme activité le petit commerce.

Madame khady est responsable du groupement,elle est âgée de 34 ans,elle est mariée et mére d'un enfant.

Son activité est la transformation de l'arachide en huile.Elle dispose d'une bonne expérience de ce type d'activité pour l'avoir pratiqué depuis plus de 02 ans.

Son prêt lui permettra d'augmenter sa capacité de production ainsi elle pourra augmenter son chiffre d'affaires.

Son objectif est d'assurer la scolarité,la nourriture et une bonne santé à ses enfants.
texts.en:
The Dioubo solidarity group has been created on May 9, 2010. It is composed of 21 women from the same village. They all work as vendors.
Mrs. Khady is the group’s leader. She is 34 years old, married and the mother of one child.

Her line of work is preparing peanut oil from peanuts. She is experienced in this trade having  practiced it for over two years. Her loan will allow her to increase her leovel of production and thus to increase her income. Her goal is to provide for the education, food and healthcare of her [child]

loans.use: to buy peanuts [ground nuts]

loans.name: Bok Diom Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité bok diom a été créé le 09/05/2010.IL regroupe 18 femmes issues du même village.
Elles ont pour activité le petit commerce.

Madame guemess en position debout et à l'extreme droite sur la photo,est responsable du groupement,elle est âgée de 43 ans,elle est mariée et a en charge 09 enfants.

Son activité est la transformation de l'arachide en huile.Elle dispose d'une bonne expérience de ce type de commerce.

Son prêt lui permettra de s'approvisionner en arachides.

Son objectif est de participer aux charges de famille telles que la scolarité et la nourriture de ses enfants.
texts.en:
The Bok Diom solidarity group was created on 09/05/2010. The group is composed of 18 women from the same village, all with small retail businesses.

Guemess, standing on the far right of the picture, is the group's leader. She is 43 and is married and supports 9 children. She works producing groundnut oil, an activity she is very experienced in. The loan would go towards buying more groundnuts. Guemess' aim is to be able to contribute towards the household expenses, including feeding her children and putting them through school.

loans.use: to buy groundnuts

loans.name: Deggo Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité deggo a été créé le 07/05/2010.IL est composé de 23 membres femmes issues du même village.Elles ont pour activité principale le petit commerce.

Madame Fatou en position debout  sur la photo et à l'extreme droite,est la responsable du groupement.Elle est âgée de 46 ans et s'occupe de 13 enfants.

Son activité consiste à faire une transformation de l'arachide en huile,elle dispose d'une expérience moyenne pour ce type de commerce.

Son prêt lui permettra de s'approvisionner en quantité suffisante d'arachide pour obtenir une meilleure production.

Son objectif est de renforcer son épargne et de faire de l'élevage.
texts.en:
The Deggo solidarity group was created on May 7, 2010. It consists of 23 women from the same village who mainly conduct small trade.

Mrs Fatou, standing on the far right-hand side of the photo, chairs the group. She is 46 years old and cares for 13 children. She produces groundnut oil and has medium experience in this activity. She will use her loan to buy a sizeable amount of groundnuts to get a good production volume. Her goal is to bolster her saving level and rear cattle.

loans.use: to buy groundnuts to produce oil.

loans.name: Fatma

texts.en:
Fatma is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a Khanga’s, handbags and shoes selling business. (Khanga's are traditional pieces of fabric worn by East African women) She sells at retail and from door to door to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of Khanga’s, handbags, and shoes. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of Khanga’s, hand bags, and shoes.

loans.name: Wazo Tegeta Group

texts.en:
Rose, who is in her late 20s, is married.  She has been a food vendor for one year now. She works from 6 am to 8 pm daily and is able to make a small monthly profit.

This will be her 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to pay school fees, to buy a small amount of cooking oil, 25 kilos of baking flour and to replace the missing items in her food stock. She has paid back all her loans successfully.  She wants a loan to buy a small amount of cooking oil, 20kls baking flour, 20kls of sugar and a sack of charcoal. Her dream is to one day own a restaurant.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Wazo Hill" which has a total of 23 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy a small amount of cooking oil, 20kls baking flour, 20kls of sugar and a sack of charcoal.

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past year, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of green vegetables, fruits and tomatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of green vegetables, fruits and tomatoes.

loans.name: Nigina

texts.ru: Нигина проживает в районе Яван. Ей 35 лет. Она замужем. У нее пятеро детей. Ее муж работает врачом в поликлинике района. Сама Нигина более десяти лет занимается животноводством. Она разводит крупнорогатый скот у себя дома. Она разводит скот в дальнейшем для продажи. Кредит берет для закупа скота, чтобы увеличить их количество.
texts.en: Nigina lives in the Yavan region. She is 35 years old and married. She has five children. Her husband works as a doctor in an area clinic. Nigina herself has practiced animal husbandry for more than ten years. She breeds cattle at her home for future sale. She is requesting a loan to purchase livestock in order to increase her herd.

loans.use: purchase livestock.

loans.name: Foreya Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 12 juin 2008. Il est composé de quinze femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Mama qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 36 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de six enfants. 

Elle s’active dans la vente de poissons frais. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, pour l'avoir pratiquer depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités de vente de poissons frais.

Les profits générés par son petit commerce de poissons frais lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…).
texts.en:
The Foreya solidarity group was created on June 12, 2008. It consists of 15 women from the same neighborhood who mainly conduct small trade.

Mrs Mama, standing on the right-hand side of the photo and raising her hand, chairs the group. She is 36 years old, married and the mother of six children. She sells fresh fish. She has a lot of experience in this activity after having been a fish seller for several years. She will use her loan to increase her working capital, develop her business and buy fresh fish for resale. The profit from her activity will enable her to improve the living standard of her family (healthcare, food, clothing, etc.).

loans.use: to buy fresh fish.

loans.name: Aba Ndiaye Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 12 juin 2008. Il est  composé de quinze femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.

Madame Fatou qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est responsable du groupe. Elle est âgée de 53 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de cinq enfants. Elle a aussi en sa charge quatre autres enfants confiés par ses parents.

Elle s’active dans la vente de l'huile de palme et de jus de citron. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité qu'elle pratique depuis plusieurs années.

Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.

Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…) et d’augmenter ses épargnes.
texts.en:
The Aba N. solidarity group was created on June 12, 2008. It consists of 15 women from the same neighborhood who mainly conduct small trade.

Mrs Fatou, standing on the right-hand side of the photo and raising her hand, chairs the group. She is 53 years old, married and the mother of five children. She also takes care of four other children that their parents entrusted to her care. She sells palm oil and lemon juice. After several years in this activity she has a lot of experience. She will use her loan to increase her working capital and develop her business. The profit from her activity will enable her to improve the living standard of her family (healthcare, food, clothing, etc.) and save more money.

loans.use: to buy palm oil and lemon juice.

loans.name: Tindolo

texts.en:
Tindolo is 45 years old. She is a widow with three children. One of her children is in school. She has a business of selling groundnuts in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years.

Tindolo requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She says that she will use the profit from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more groundnuts to sell

loans.name: Serigne Bara Mbacke Group

texts.fr:
LE groupe de solidarité Serigne Bara est crée le 14 décembre 2008. Il regroupe 20 femmes. Les membres habitent le même quartier et entretiennent d'excellentes relations. Leurs activités principales est le petit commerce et l'embouche.

La présidente Mame Daro est âgée de 43 ans, mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Elle est vendeuse de poisson au marché central de poisson de la ville. Dés fois elle vend des habits.
Avec son Prêt elle veut acheter des marchandises. C'est son mari et elle qui gèrent la maison.  

Sur la photo elle est tout à fait à droite la main levée.
texts.en:
The Serigne Bara Mbacke solidarity group was created on December 14, 2008. It consists of 20 women from the same neighborhood. The relationship between them is very cordial. They mainly conduct small trade and cattle rearing.

Mrs Daro is 43 years old, married and the mother of six children. She sells fish at the main fish market in town. Sometimes she sells clothes. She will use her loan to buy goods for resale. She and her husband provide together for the household. Mrs Daro is standing on the far right-hand side of the photo and raising her hand.

loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Sop Serigne Fallou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Sop Serigne Fallou est créé depuis le 28 juin 2010, il est composé de 13 femmes qui sont parentes, voisines et sont en bonne entente. Le petit commerce est leur activité principale.

La présidente du groupe Maty , âgée de 36 ans est mariée et mère de 05 enfants. Elle vend de l'encens, des parfums, de la glace et des jus. Elle mène cette activité depuis 1 an et demi. Elle fait aussi de l'embouche depuis 6 mois.

Elle voudrait avec son prêt acheter des sujets, de l'encens et des parfums.

Elle et son mari gèrent la famille. Sur la photo elle est debout à droite et a la main gauche levée.
texts.en:
The Sop Serigne Fallou solidarity group was created on June 28, 2010. It consists of 13 women who know each other through ties of kinship and neighborhood. The relationship between them is cordial. They mainly conduct small trade.

Maty, who chairs the group, is 36 years old, married and the mother of five children. She sells incense, perfume, ice cream and juice. She has been in this business for one and a half years. In addition, she has been rearing cattle for six months. She will use her loan to buy merchandise, incense and perfume. She and her husband provide for the family. Maty is standing on the right-hand side of the photo and raising her left hand.

loans.use: to buy merchandise.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman who owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past ten years, she has operated a food vending business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to purchase sacks of rice, sugar, salt and charcoal. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of rice, sugar, salt and charcoal.

loans.name: Jappo Liggey Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Jappo Liggey du banc villageois TouB. Séras 2 est un groupe de 14 membres. Le groupe est crée depuis le 14 décembre 2008. Les membres sont des voisines et ont comme activité commune le petit commerce.

La présidente du groupe Seynabou âgée de 42 ans est une femme mariée,  mère de 04 enfants et qui a une nièce à sa charge. Elle fait du petit commerce. Elle vend des fleurs aromatiques "nana" depuis 06 ans. Elle fait aussi de l'embouche de mouton, canard et poulet.

Avec son prêt elle voudrait acheter des sujets, du "nana" et de l'engrais. Avec ses bénéfices elle aide son mari pour les charges de la maison. Sur la photo elle est à droite en rouge avec une écharpe blanche.
texts.en:
Jappo Liggey Group, belonging to the Banc Villageois TouB. Séras 2, was created on December 14, 2008. It consists of 14 women who are neighbors and conduct small trade.

Seynabou, who chairs the group, is 42 years old, married and the mother of four children. Her niece, too, is in her care. She is a small retailer and has been selling aromatic "nana" flowers for six years. In addition, she breeds sheep, ducks and chickens. She will use her loan to buy merchandise, "nana" flours and fertilizer. She will use her profit to help her husband with household expenditures. Seynabou is standing on the right-hand side of the photo, wearing a reddish dress and a white scarf.

loans.use: to buy merchandise, aromatic flowers and fertilizer.

loans.name: Songama Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 12 juin 2008. Le groupe est  composé de quinze femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le petit commerce.
Madame Rohetou qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main et le responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 38 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de cinq enfants. Elle a aussi en sa charge deux autres enfants confié par ses parents.
Elle s’active dans la vente de bananes. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, car étant pratiquer depuis plusieurs années.
Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.
Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…) et d’augmenter ses épargnes.
texts.en:
The Songama solidarity group was created on June 12, 2008. It consists of 15 women from the same neighborhood who mainly conduct small trade.

Mrs Rohetou, standing on the right-hand side of the photo and raising her hand, chairs the group. She is 38 years old, married and the mother of five children. She also takes care of two other children that their parents entrusted to her care. She sells bananas. After several years in this activity she has a lot of experience. She will use her loan to increase her working capital and develop her business. The profit from her activity will enable her to improve the living standard of her family (healthcare, food, clothing, etc.) and save more money.

loans.use: to buy bananas.

loans.name: Khanga Group

texts.en:
Fatuma, who is in her mid 20s, is married with one child who goes to school.  She has had a business of selling charcoal since 2004. She works from 8am to 6pm daily and is able to make a fair monthly profit. 

This will be her 6th loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to buy more sacks of charcoal, bought a TV and a big radio, bought some land and paid household expenses. She has paid back all her loans successfully. She wants a loan to buy more sacks of charcoal. Her dream is to one day be able to build a house. 

She will share this loan with her loan group "Khanga", which has a total of 16 members who will hold each other accountable is paying back their loans.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sacks of fish, coconuts and bundles of wheat flour.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 40 years old and married with six children. Three of her children are in school. She has a business selling charcoal in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for four years.

Mary requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
This is Gemma, 45, a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. She’s married to Vicencio, a driver, and the mother to her four children. The oldest is already working while the youngest is in elementary school.  At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for everyday expenses and to save for the future of her children.

Gemma operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five peso's-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Gemma earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 450 Philippine Pesos in sales every day.   

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects an increase in her business income as she expands her business. 

Gemma hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Akbari's Group

texts.en:
Akbari is a very active lady who supports her family by sewing clothes for her neighboring clients. She is very good at her work and prepares beautiful looking clothes by using laces & ribbons. She earns good profits. Her husband is 45 years old and a janitor in the university. 

Akbari has five children. Her youngest child is in fourth class. The other children left their education in their teen-age years and started work to contribute to the family financially. She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her son who has a business making & selling snacks. He makes snacks using a snack-maker machine and sells to his local area clients. He generates income for the family. His clientele base is children and his snacks are very famous among them.  

With the loan, he will buy required ingredients such as gram flour, cumin seeds and cooking oil in bulk quantity and repair the snack-maker to be able to make a larger number of snacks to sell and increase his profits.
 
Akbari hopes that an investment will be a profitable one for her son's business.

loans.use: To buy required ingredients & repair the snack maker

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase barbed wire for constructing zero grazing unit.

loans.name: Battuya

texts.en:
Battuya is married and lives with her four children and her husband in the Chingeltei district of Ulaanbaatar city in Mongolia. Her two eldest children are college students at the Ulaanbaatar college. They work during the summer break to pay their college tuition fees. 

Battuya started sewing clothes at Huchit Shonhor market in 2007. Before starting her business career, she worked at the children's clothes sewing factory. When there is high demand, she temporarily hires another tailor and pays for their transportation and lunch costs in addition to their salary. 

In the future, she plans to rent a commercial space at Bombogor market and expand her business activity. She is a hard-working, open-minded, and diligent woman who is requesting a 1,200,000 MNT loan to purchase a sewing machine and expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cloth materials for her sewing business.

loans.name: Mejumaa

texts.en:
Mejumaa, a married woman with five children, two boys and three girls, owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. School fees constitute her greatest monthly expense.

For the last five years, Mejumaa has operated a firewood and charcoal-selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces the major challenge of price fluctuation in the market and dreams of establishing another outlet in the future.

Having joined Yehu to access loans to boost her business, Mejumaa wishes to borrow Kshs 40,000 in order to purchase bundles of firewood and sacks of charcoal.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood and sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
This is Fe, 44, a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Cesar, a draftsman, and mother to her only child, who is already in college. By the grace of God, Fe has managed to support her child’s schooling up to college level. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her family's everyday expenses.

Fe operates a variety store which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store retailing groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five pesos' worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Fe earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house, and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales each day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php17,000 loan in order to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Fe hopes her business grows into a mini-grocery and dreams of enabling her child to achieve a good and high quality education through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God that she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. Composed of 15 to 30 community partners, each fellowship group gathers weekly to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Djamadjigui Group

texts.fr:
le groupe de solidarité djamadjigui a été crée le 20 Juin 2009 à l'inauguration du banc villageois. Il est composé de 22 femmes toutes issues du même quartier et exerçant comme activité principale le petit commerce. 

Debout à l'extrême droite de la photo et levant la main, la responsable est âgée de 57 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. 

Elle vend des fruits comme les mangues, les bananes, et les oranges. elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d'activité pour l'avoir exercer pendant une dizaine d'années. 

Avec ce prêt, elle pourra acheter des mangues, bananes, oranges pour la revente. 

Avec les bénéfices qu'elle tirera de son activité, elle compte aider dans la prise en charge de sa famille.
texts.en:
The Djamadjigui solidarity group was created on June 20, 2009, when its Banc Villageois was opened. It consists of 22 women from the same neighborhood who mainly conduct small trade.

The president of the group is standing on the far right-hand side of the photo and raises her hand. She is 57 years old, married and the mother of six children. She sells fruit, such as mangoes, bananas and oranges. After some ten years in this activity she has a lot of experience. She will use her loan to buy mangoes, bananas and oranges for resale. She intends to spend the profit from her activity on household expenditures.

loans.use: to buy bananas, mangoes and oranges.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with one girl who attends school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past seven years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation of products in the market. Her major dream is to establish a retail shop in the future. 

With the 20,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) she wants to start another business of selling water, purchasing taps and water pipes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To start another business of selling water, purchase taps and water pipes.

loans.name: Ktim Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe KITIM a été créé le 22 Avril  2007 lors de l’inauguration leur banc villageois. Il compte 22 femmes qui habitent toutes le même village. Elles font toutes le petit commerce.

Madame Baldé est responsable. Elle est âgée de 47 ans, est mariée et mère de cinq enfants. Elle a en charge  une belle sœur.

Elle vend  sucre, du thé, du savon et divers produits de consommation courante. Activité qu’elle exerce de puis plus de six ans, au paravent elle pratiquait l’agriculture.

Son prêt va lui permettre de mieux s’approvisionner en sucre, thé et savon pour la revente.

Les bénéfices lui serviront d’augmenter d’épargne en parti, et de soutenir son mari dans les charges familiales.
texts.en:
The group KITIM was created on April 22, 2007 when their Banc Villageois was inaugurated. The group comprises 22 women who all live in the same village. They all have small businesses. 

Ms. Baldé is the group's official. She is 47 years old, married, and the mother of five children. She supports her sister-in-law. 

Ms. Baldé sells sugar, tea, soap, and a variety of other typical consumer items. She has been in this business for over six years. In the past, she used to grow crops. 

Her loan is going to enable her to do better supplying herself with sugar, tea, and soap to resell. She will use the profits in part to increase her savings and to support her husband in covering family expenses.

loans.use: to stock up on sugar, tea, and soap to resell

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice is 35 years old. She is a widow with four children, all of whom are in school. She has a business selling bread and onions in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years.

Joice requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She will use the profit to pay for school fees for her children.

loans.use: to purchase more onions and bread to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase 20 sacks of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Bëg Diam Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Bëg Diam est créé le 14 décembre 2008, il est composé de dix huit femmes qui sont sœurs, amies et voisines;elles exercent les mêmes activités de petit commerce et d'embouche.

Madame Ndéye la responsable est âgée de 54 ans, elle est mariée mère de huit enfants et a deux autres qui lui ont été confiés; elle mène une activité de petit commerce de diverses marchandises, elle fait parallèlement de l'embouche, elle a une bonne expérience. Elle est debout tout à fait à droite habillée en boubou teinté noir avec couleurs rose jaune.


Elle s'approvisionne dans un pays frontalier en Mauritanie et revend dans son quartier.


Son prêt lui servira à renforcer son activité afin de gagner beaucoup de revenus.

Elle souhaite augmenter son épargne avec les bénéfices obtenus.
texts.en: The solidarity group Bëg Diam was created on December 14, 2008. It comprises eighteen women who are sisters, friends, and neighbors; they all have the same work in small-scale commerce and in livestock farming. Ms. Ndéy, the group's official, is 54 years old, married, and the mother of eight children, plus two others who have been entrusted to her. She runs a small business selling a variety of merchandise. At the same time, she fattens livestock. She has good experience. In the photo, she is the one standing at the far right and dressed in a boubou dyed black with pink and yellow. She gets her supplies from the bordering country of Mauritania and resells them in her district. Her loan will be used to bolster her business in order to earn a lot of revenues. She wishes to save more money with the profits obtained.

loans.use: to buy merchandise to sell

loans.name: Ngboman Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe existe depuis le 12 juin 2008. Le nom est en langue Mankagne et signifie " faisons", pour monter la bravoure de ses membres. Le commerce est leur principale activité même si certaines cultive elles-mêmes leurs produits.
Mme Sabdou est la responsable du groupe. Sur la photo, elle est à droite avec la main gauche levée. Elle est âgée de 40 ans, mariée et mère de 07 enfants. Elle a aussi 05 autres personnes sous sa responsabilité.
Son activité est le jardinage. Elle cultive plusieurs variétés de légumes qu'elle met en vente au marché hebdomadaire de son village. Elle exerce depuis les années 90 et elle a une maitrise du secteur et des cultures.
Ce prêt lui permet d'acheter des semences, des insecticides et autres produits pour se garantir une bonne récolte.
Les bénéfices lui serviront d'épargne mensuelle, mais également d'assouvir ses besoins personnels et familiaux.
texts.en:
This group has been in existence since June 2008. In the Mankagne language, the group’s name means “Let's make it happen" so as to indicate the valor of its members. They mainly work in commerce, while some of them grow their own products. 

Ms. Sabdou is the group’s official. In the photo, she is on the right with her left hand raised. She is 40 years old, married, and the mother of seven children. She is also responsible for five other persons. Her business involves gardening. She grows several varieties of vegetables that she puts up for sale at the weekly market in her village. She has been in this business since the 1990’s and has a command of this sector and crops. 

This loan will enable her to buy seeds, insecticides, and other items to guarantee a good harvest. She will use the profits to save money each mont but also to meet personal and family needs.

loans.use: to grow vegetables

loans.name: Koute Djomboulou Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe a été crée à l'assemblée constitutive du BV le 12 juin 2008. IL regroupe 15 membres du même village et qui font la même activité:produire et vendre du "nététou". Le nom du groupe signifie "l'homme propose, Dieu dispose".
Mme Fatou qui est en haut à droite de la photo est la responsable du groupe. Elle est mariée et elle a 04 enfants et 02 autres personnes à la charge de son époux.
Elle s'active dans la production et la vente de "nététou" (graine de néré transformée) depuis plus de 10 ans.
Ce crédit lui permettra d'augmenter sa production et de faire plus de profits.
Avec ces profits, Mme Fatou compte s'acheter un matelas et aider aussi son époux pour la prise en charge de la famille.
texts.en:
This group was created at the founding assembly of the Banc Villageois on June 12, 2008. It consists of 15 members from the same village who also practice the same activity, namely producing and selling "nététou", a typical African condiment. The group's name means "man proposes, God disposes."

Mrs. Fatou, at the top right of the photo, is the head of the group. She is married with four children, and two more people are in her husband’s care. She has been making and selling nététou (processed locust seed) for over 10 years. 

This loan will allow her to bolster her production and increase her profits, which she will use to buy a mattress and help her husband to support the family.

loans.use: to buy locust seeds and make "nététou"

loans.name: Tsiala

texts.en:
Tsiala is from the village Sartichala, in the Kakheti region. She is 47 years old and lives with her family–her husband Guram and 18-year-old daughter Tamta. 

Guram works in the village, mainly on agricultural works in his and nearby villages. Tsiala is leading the dairy farm owned by the family. They have three milk cows. Tsiala produces yogurt and cheese from the milk and sells them in Tbilisi (capital city of the country). She takes them once a week to the Tbilisi open market and sells to dairy product retailers. Total average income of the family is 650 Laris per month. 

Tsiala requested credit for purchasing an additional milk cow. She will be able to increase the production and sales of dairy products by 30-35%. The income of the family will increase. Tsiala plans to purchase new household goods, in order to make their house more comfortable.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Everline

texts.en:
Everline is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For the past two years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces the major challenge of the high cost of transportation in her business. She dreams of expanding her business and becoming self reliant in the future.

With the KSHS 10,000, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal, maize flour, sugar, cooking fat oil and washing detergents. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal, maize flour, sugar, cooking fat oil and washing detergents.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 22 years old and married with one child who is in school. She has a business selling beans, sorghum and cooking oil in Kator Branch in South Sudan. She has been in this business for three years.

Rose requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business.

loans.use: to purchase more sorghum and beans to sell

loans.name: Aymunas

texts.ru: Аймунас проживает в районе Яван. Возраст, 61 год. Она вдова. У нее пятеро детей. Ее сын находится на заработках в России. Сама Аймунас зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. Она покупает телят, откармливает, а потом через несколько месяцев продает. Этим видом деятельности она занимается 18 лет. Кредит берет для закупа телят.
texts.en: Aymunas lives in the Yavan region. She is 61 years old. She is a widow with five children. Her son is making a living in Russia. Aymunas earns her income by breeding cattle. She buys calves, fattens them up and sells them after a few months. She has been in this line of work for 18 years. She is requesting a loan to purchase a calf.

loans.use: Purchase a calf

loans.name: Abdoul  Bâ Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Abdoul Bâ a été crée le 23 Juillet 2011 à l'inauguration du banc villageois. Il est composé de 13 femmes toutes issues du même village. Elles ont comme principale activité le petit commerce. 

Debout à l'extrême droite de la photo et levant la main, la responsable du groupe est âgée de 62 ans . Elle n'a pas eu d'enfants à elle mais a la charge des orphelins que lui a laissé son défunt frère et qui sont au nombre de cinq en plus de leur maman. 

Elle vend du riz, du sucre et de la cola.Elle a une bonne expérience de son activité pour l'avoir pratiquer depuis plus de trois années. 

Ce nouveau crédit lui permettra de s'approvisionner en riz, sucre et cola pour la revente. 

Avec les bénéfices qu'elle tirera de son activité, elle compte renforcer ses épargnes pour une partie et l'autre améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
The solidarity group Abdoul Bâ was created on July 23, 2011 at the inauguration of the "village bank". It is composed of 13 women who all come from the same village. Their principal activity is small-scale retail business. 

Standing on the far right in the photo and raising her hand is the group leader, aged 62. She has no children but she is caring for her deceased brother's five children as well as for his wife. 

She sells rice, sugar and kola nuts. She has a lot of experience in her business as she has been in it for three years. 

This new loan will permit her to stock up on rice, sugar and kola nuts for resale. With the profit from this business, she intends to save more on the one hand, but also improve living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to buy merchandise (rice, sugar, and kola nuts)

loans.name: Sans Probleme Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe est créé le 12 juin 2008 à l'ouverture du BV. Ses membres habitent le même village et ont pour activité principale le commerce de légumes.
Mme Khady est une veuve de 40 ans, avec 06 enfants à sa charge. Elle est responsable du groupe et sur la photo, elle est à droite avec la main levée.
Elle s'active dans le petit commerce de légumes avec un étal devant sa maison. Elle est très expérimentée vu le nombre d'années de pratique ( 15 ans).
Ce prêt lui permettra de s'approvisionner en gros au marché hebdomadaire pour vendre en détail chez elle. Cela développera son commerce puisque ses charges sont réduites.
Les bénéfices serviront à renforcer son épargne et à entretenir sa famille, surtout la santé, la nourriture et la scolarité de ses enfants.
texts.en:
This group was created on June 12, 2008 at the opening of the BV ("village bank"). Its members all live in the same village and their primary business is selling vegetables. 

Mme Khady is a widow of 40, raising six children. She is the leader of the group and in the photo she is on the right with her hand raised. 

She is a small-scale retailer selling vegetables from a stall in front of her house. She has a lot of experience as she has done this business for 15 years. 

This loan will permit her to stock up at the weekly wholesale market so as to sell retail at her house. This will expand her business since her expenses will be reduced. 

Her profit will be used to grow her savings and support her family, especially relative to their health, food, and school fees for the children.

loans.use: to buy vegetables.

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is a married man who lives in a rental house that has electricity but no piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are rent and transport costs. 

Nicholas operates a hawking business, selling clothes from door-to-door to his neighbors and passersby. He faces the major challenge of high cost of transportation while moving from door to door. He dreams of expanding to open a clothes-selling stall in the future.

With the KSHS 20,000, he wants to purchase two bales of secondhand clothes for resale. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase two bales of secondhand clothes for resale.

loans.name: Tessito Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tessito est créé le 12 juin 2008 à l'ouverture du BV. Le nom Tessito signifie " serrer la ceinture" en langue locale mandingue. Ses membres sont du même village et font du jardinage dans la même zone.
Mme Mariama est née en 1971 et elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Sur la photo, est est habillée en blanc, à gauche avec un foulard blanc sur la tête. Elle est la responsable du groupe depuis sa création.
Elle s'active dans la culture de légumes depuis plus de 10 ans et elle encadre d'autres femmes dans ce domaine.
Ce prêt va lui permettre d'augmenter sa production et de faire plus de profits.
Les bénéfices serviront aux besoins familiaux et surtout elle compte acheter un matelas.
texts.en:
The Tessito group was formed on June 12, 2008 at the opening of the BV ("village bank"). The name Tessito means "tighten your belt" in the local Mandinka language. Its members are all from the same village and do gardening in the same area. 

Mme Mariama was born in 1971 and she is married and the mother of six children. In the photo she is the one dressed in white, on the left, with a white scarf on her head. She has been the group leader since the group came into being. 

She has worked growing vegetables for more than 10 years and has gotten other women into this field. The loan will allow her to produce more and make more profit. The profit will be used for family needs and especially, she is intending to buy a mattress.

loans.use: to use to do gardening.

loans.name: Melecio

texts.en:
This is Melecio, 22, a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. He is single and manages his own home while operating a business. He works hard to sustain himself and continually provide income for his everyday expenses.

Melecio is a fish vendor. He buys different kinds of fish at wholesale prices and sells them by the kilo. His store is located in a temporary fish market. There are many patrons who prefer Melecio’s products since they are assured of its freshness and cleanliness; they regularly anticipate his fish. His regular customers are his neighbors and the local community.  He earns a minimum of PHP 400 in sales every day. To help him continue operations of his business, he is requesting a loan of PHP 8,000. He will be using the loan to buy more fish to sell every day. He expects a boost in his business income as he expands his business. 

Melecio hopes that his business will continue to be successful. He faithfully meets up with his co-fellowship members to share stories of his work every week, and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional fish

loans.name: Coumba O. Diatta Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité CoumB. O. Diatta a été crée le 23 Juillet 2011 à l'inauguration du banc villageois. Il est composé de 31 femmes toutes issues du même village et menant comme activité principale le petit commerce. 

Debout à l'extrême droite de la photo et levant la main, la responsable est âgée de 39 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de trois enfants. 

Elle vend du sucre, de la cigarette et du thé. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine pour l'avoir pratiqué au moins trois ans. 

ce nouveau prêt lui permettra de s'approvisionner en sucre, cigarettes et thé pour la revente. 

Avec les intérêts générés, elle compte aider son mari dans la prise en charge des besoins de la famille et surtout des enfants.
texts.en:
The solidarity group CoumB. O. Diatta was created on July 23, 2011 when the Banc Villageois was inaugurated. The group comprises 31 women all from the same village. Their main work involves small businesses. 

Standing with her hand raised at the far right in the photo, the group's official is 39 years old, married, and the mother of three children. She sells sugar, cigarettes, and tea.  She has good experience in this domain for having worked in it for at least three years.

This new loan will enable her to stock up on sugar, cigarettes, and tea to resell.

With the profits generated, she plans on helping out her husband in meeting the needs of the family and especially those of the children.

loans.use: to buy merchandise (sugar, cigarettes, and tea)

loans.name: Souleye Dème Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité Soulèye Dème a été crée le 23 Juillet 2011 à l'inauguration de leur banc villageois. Il est composé de 31 femmes toutes issues du m^me village. elles ont comme activité principale le petit commerce.

Debout à l'extrême droite de la photo et levant la main en arrière plan, la responsable est âgée de 44 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de sept enfants. 

Elle vend du riz, de l'huile et de la cola. Elle maitrise bien son activité pour l'avoir pratiquée pendant bon nombre d'années. 

Ce nouveau prêt lui permettra de s'approvisionner en riz , huile et cola pour la revente. 

Avec les bénéfices générés par le prêt, elle compte améliorer les conditions de vie de sa progéniture et aider son mari dans les charges.
texts.en:
The solidarity group Soulèye Dème was created on July 23, 2011 when the Banc Villageois was inaugurated. The group comprises 31 women all from the same village. Their main work involves small businesses. 

Standing with her hand raised in the back row at the far right in the photo, the group's official is 44 years old, married, and the mother of seven children. She sells rice, oil, and cola. She has a good command of her business for having worked in it for a number of years.

This new loan will enable her to stock up on rice, oil, and cola to resell.

With the profits generated by this loan, she plans on improving her children's living conditions and to help her husband with expenses.

loans.use: to buy merchandise (rice, oil, and some cola)

loans.name: Jappo Group

texts.fr:
